raw_response: {"answer_index": 0, "answer_text": "Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus", "confidence": 10, "reasoning": "This young woman presents with bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO)—adduction deficit in each eye with contralateral abducting nystagmus—without other cranial nerve deficits. INO is caused by a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which coordinates conjugate horizontal gaze. Bilateral INO in a young adult is classically due to demyelination, most commonly multiple sclerosis. Other options (tumor, infarction, thiamine deficiency) are less likely to cause isolated, bilateral MLF lesions in this age group."}
